My favorite along these lines is the portrait of Picasso made by Gjon Mili. Done just as Stephen describes: shutter open in dark room, Picasso draws figure, at very end pop flash, close shutter.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071010133948im_/http:/typophile.com/files/mili_picasso_6620.jpg)

or if you are not a purist.

Import or scan your base ’type’ design.  
Needs to have a photographic background or similar to work, like in your example  
Copy the ’type’ layer in Photoshop four/five+ times.  
Blur each layer to different amounts, nudge them about a bit, alter the colours, impose different blends on each color dodge/screen/overlay.  
Basically experiment to you find what you are looking for.

Yep, along with belleisle advice there’s lots of ways to achieve the neon glow effect in Photoshop.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071010133948im_/http:/typophile.com/files/GlowLines_4921.JPG)

One real simple way is to use the Pen tool to create your shapes and on a new layer above it fill with colour and set the blending mode to Color. You could copy your shape to a new layer below it and apply to slight gauss blurr to achieve a diffused effect. In my example I just used two layers on a black bg.

clauses, groovy linkage. Check out camera tossing on Flickr: [http://www.flickr.com/search/?q=camera+tossing](http://web.archive.org/web/20071010133948/http:/www.flickr.com/search/?q=camera+tossing "http://www.flickr.com/search/?q=camera+tossing")
